root.pub-comments: The author claims the possibility of this family to be related to the Carib stock, but at the time had no proof and thus classified it as an isolate. The author recognizes these as settlements of speakers of this language: Patica, Saturiwa, Atore, Homolua, Alimacani, Casti, Malica, Melona, Timoga, Enecaqua, Choya, Edelano, Astina, Utina, Patchica, Chilili, Calanay, Onochaquara, Mayarca, Mathiaca, Maiera, Mocoso, Cadica, Eloquale, Aquonena, Hicaranaou, Appalou, Oustaca, Onathcaqua, Potanou, Ehiamana, Anouala, Mocossou, Oathcaqua, Sorrochos, Hanocoroucouay, Marracou, Hiouacara, Acquera, Aguile, Basisa, Vacissa, Cholupaha, Hapaluya, Hirrihiqua, Itafi, San Mateo, Santa Lucia de Acuera, Tacatacuru, Tocaste, Tolemato, Topoqui, Itara, Napetuca, Osile, San Juan de Guaraca, Tucururu, Ucita, Urriparacuxi, and Yupaha.
root.publications: Powell, J. W. 1891. Indian Linguistic Families of America North of Mexico, 1-142. Washington D.C.: Government Printing Office.

child.pub-comments: The settlements now recognized as dialects are: Itafi, Acuera, Tucururu, and Utina.
child.geography: Spoken on the shores of St. John's River and on the Floridian coast
child.publications: Powell, J. W. 1891. Indian Linguistic Families of America North of Mexico, 1-142. Washington D.C.: Government Printing Office.
